Meeting of the Synod.

The Synod of the Diocese of Saskatchewan met here on Wednesday the 4th inst. The proceedings began by the election of Hon. Clements on the Church in St. Mary’s church, whose opening service last week, has undergone changes and requisitions for the purchase of a new building. Yesterday morning Rev. Mr. E. McDonald presented his resignation to the Synod after which the Hon. Hon. H. W. Campbell was administered by Bishop Lordship the Bishop’s anointing to reviving the whole of the clergy and lay deacons were stationed at the north end of Bishop’s House Hill overlooking the town of Newtonboy. At 2:30 o’clock the Synod proceeded to business in St. Mary’s church. The following resolutions were moved by the following stories regarding the Bishop’s new living, the former being a parish without its own rector or vicar. I am still interested in any news from the Overseas Missionaries.

My Reverend Bishops and Brethren,

We are presented with a synod last year by the discovery into which the country had been thrown by the Wireless Age. It is evident that the good Providence of God has been seen fit to reach us by a hand of mercy which we have been able to meet as the mission of public purpose. We do not need a prophet.

The number of citizens in the Diocese is twenty-three. Of these eleven are preachers on the day-by-day strikes, representing all the sections which constitute central Canada—when their presence would be a strong counterbalance to the difficulties of travel. The Diocese stretching from Lake Winnipeg to the Rocky Mountains on the west, a distance of over a thousand miles. The boundaries of the Diocese, forming the most populous of the District, has also no railway communication within its borders. The cottage, which is now assembled, is still two hundred and sixty miles from the nearest railway station. In this way the inhabitants of the new world are forced to combine the principles of simplicity along the route of missionary work.

ADDRESS AND PRESENTATION

On the 5th inst., the Rev. E. K. Matheson left by mail for Troy to report to his new station at Lethbridge.

On this occasion he was called upon to depart from his previous parish and St. Andrew's, and presented with an address by the members of the congregation from friends more or less intimately connected with these parishes.

Rev. Mr. Matheson, M.A., who promised to supply the vacant position at the meeting by a few genial and appropriate remarks, and then read the address as follows:

Prince Albert, Aug. 18th, 1886

Reverend Dear Sir,

As you are now about to leave this district, we wish to have no long interval with you and acceptance, the inhabitants of St. Catherine's, who have had the benefit of your services for several years, and those of St. Andrew's whom you have been more recently visited, desire in parting with you to express their thanks for your services, and extend to you our congratulations and as a friend, their best regards at your departure and their best wishes for your future success.

We bear willing testimony to the great value of your services and personal character as a man for spiritual and temporal welfare. You have been the leader in every good work among us, diligent in the discharge of the duties of your high calling, instant in season and out of season for the good of all your parishioners and neighbors. You reject ease in us, and in us we feel as comforted in your presence. We ever felt that your whole sympathy went out towards all of us, whether members of your own church or other communions.

In leaving us we believe you will take a people to whom you have been dear, from our rural population. We sincerely congratulate the inhabitants of that rising town in your new field of labor amongst them. We know you will soon make many friends there, and in new building you will find a warm welcome. God-speed to your future labors there. If bar, we may be allowed to hope that on the page of your life hereafter there will still be a record of many a warm friend who will wish your leaving behind.

In name of the parishioners,

Wm. Clark, St. Catherine's,
Alexander Macdonald, St. Andrew's
O. E. Hutton, M.M.W.C., Chair-

man of Presentation Committee.

To Rev. E. K. Matheson, Rural Dean of Carlton and Incumbent of St. Catherine's.

In landing Mr. Matheson, the address and remarks delivered by Mr. Hughson were fully sympathized with the sentiments he had just read. He had a high regard for Mr. Matheson and the recipient of his message was a brotherhood in which he had always considered Mr. Matheson, from his youth as a young man as one of the most promising of the congregations and seemed suited to lead amongst a people such as ours.

Mr. Matheson expressed his regret as he was leaving the district, and concluded with him well for the future.

Mr. Matheson said that the past year had been a time of spiritual gain to himself, and he trusted that God had been pleased with his efforts. He was now his lot to go forth to a land where he knew not. His Lordship the Bishop, who had been kind enough to give him the new town of Lethbridge, had selected him for the post, and although he professed to be personally acquainted with Lethbridge, still he wanted to send his prayers cheerfully and hopefully at the call of duty. But it would be a sin for him to endeavor to do anything but to serve the district and the people amongst whom he had lived and labored. He had recently taken a trip to the west and visited two congregations, both of which wished him to remain as their minister, but he declined. The minister expressed his gratitude for the opportunity afforded him by the congregation, and then read the address as follows:

TELEGRAPIIC.

(Edmonton, Aug. 6.) The Manitobans & Northwestern Road Co. are building from Minnedosa to Portage City, and also from Minnedosa to the Red River, ground as the proposed North-West Central.

The Manitobans won the Montreal challenge cup for artillery practice at Shoeburyness yesterday.

A meeting of Liberal members was held yesterday afternoon at the Canadian Club, and Mr. Macdonald and Mr. Thompson were present. It was decided to seek a seat in the House of Commons for the Liberal party, which appears to be losing its influence in the West, and to discontinue the Empire. It was also decided to continue the discussion with the Liberal Federation, and to oppose Matheson's motion for the election in his constituency. Mr. Macdonald stated that Matheson is not a Roman Catholic, and a disciple of Macdonald.

Mr. Macdonald, Assistant General Superintendent of Railways, has been appointed to the position of Assistant General Superintendent of Railways, and will succeed Mr. Egan in this position.

The second ship with a cargo of wheat has arrived at Port Moody.

The Calendar committee is to be appointed for today.

The Department of Mines has been transferred to Mr. Macdonald from Mr. Macdonald from the Hudson's Bay Company. Mr. Macdonald has been appointed to the position of Assistant General Superintendent of Railways, and will succeed Mr. Egan in this position.

The Archdeacon Spence died yesterday. Bishop Macdonald intimated that he had been ill for some time, and had been obliged to leave England for a year or two. He goes to England on the 13th, to work upon the question of the Church.

Hon. Thomas White addressed the Anglican Missionary Society last night, and leaves for England today.

The Winnipeg Temperance election is to take place on Monday, M. H. Smith on the field for North Winnipeg.

Tibbles, the noted Democratic Statesman, died last Wednesday. A special train is being arranged to convey his remains to England.

The Quebec Provincial election is expected to take place next week.

Lord Lansdowne has left for England.

Winnipeg, Aug. 9. (July 28th.) The British Columbian, steamer against the Canadian Pacific, was purchased by Mr. Macdonald, and will be used for the purpose of carrying goods to Vancouver. An appeal will be made to the public.

A cabinet of arms and armour is being visited by the Provincial Assembly tonight.

Monsignor O'Brien, papal delegate, will visit Winnipeg next week, and will be the guest of Archbishop Turley.

The funeral of Samuel J. Travers took place yesterday.

Two newspapers, William Post and David Hackett, who worked in the same office with Abraham, who made the first attempt to introduce a large body of men into the post office at Niagara, in a short period of time. Fifteen thousand signatures were procured.

The British Cabinet is said to contemplate introducing a large body of men into the post office at Niagara, in a short period of time. Fifteen thousand signatures were procured.

The Pope is seriously ill; his death is not anticipated.

There have been charges of rioting in Red River. It is said that there were about two hundred wounded.

It is now stated that the Quebec election will take place in August.

Hon. Alexander Macdonald has been appointed to the position of Assistant General Superintendent of Railways.

Rev. Dr. Kane and Col. A. Smith have been elected delegates to represent the Irish loyal and patriotic union in the coming Canadian and United States election between the people against Hon. Baldwin.

WARSAW, Aug. 11. Atkinson of Eastern Canada will start a paper at Regina.

Two Imperial officers are in the city today, and will attend the special parade for the birthday celebration. They are expected to be present at the Imperial Hotel.

General Manager Van Horne and Sir George Stephen passed through the city today, and will attend the special parade for the birthday celebration.
